THE TENNIS TOURNAMENT

SWIMMING POOL AT HOMEWOOD

More Entries Than Last Year—
Consolations and Doubles Are
Unfinished.

Possible Now to Add Two More Sports—
Expected to be Completed
in Six Weeks.

The third annual tennis tournament started on the twenty-second
and has been a great success. There
were thirty-two entries in singles,
six more than last year—a very
creditable showing considering the
small number of students we have.
During the tournament some of the
best tennis which has ever been seen
at Homewood occurred. In the
first round Huck, whom many supposed would • win the tournament,
defeated Clary after the hardest
kind of a three-set match, in which
both men played fine tennis. Afterward Huck defeated Russell and
Dubray and won his way to the
finals, where he was defeated by
Perce in straight sets. In the lower
half Perce had his work cut out for
him from the beginning, afterward
winning from Catlin by default. He
defeated Mullikin in a three-set
match which lasted two days. Then
he defeated Belt by a very narrow
margin in another three-set match.
He also beat Crawford in the semifinals and Huck in the finals.
The consolations and the doubles
have not yet been finished. In the
finals in the consolations "Eddie"
Hulburt and "Jack" Fulton will
play each other. In the doubles Belt
and Dubray will play the winner of
Huck and Perce vs. Post and Clary.
Both teams have won several hard
matches—Belt and Dubray from
Fulton and Gillet, Clary and Post
from Magoffin and Russell, and
Huck and Perce from Corner and
Corner.
Attention, Seniors! It wO'uld be
a good thing if all the present graduating class would sign up for THE
NEWS-LETTER for next year without having to be requested by•mail
in the fall to do so. Just sign the
blank in this copy of the paper and
leave it at THE NEWS-LETTER box.

It was announced this week that
the trustees are now building a
swimming pool at Homewood. The
pool, which will be within sight of
the boulevard, will cover about an
acre of ground. It will be about
seven feet deep. • One end—the
dam—will be of concrete. There
will be a sand bottom. The water
will be supplied from a number of
springs. In addition to being used
as a swimming pool, it will be a
skating pond in the winter. Possibly we may even be able to form
a hockey team. And we ought certainly be able now to have a swimming team. The pool will also be
used in the summer to supply water .to sprinkle the field with when
the cif,r cuts off the supply on, account of drouth.
Let's go overboard!
Dr. Henry G. Barbour (M. D.
'io), fellow in pathology, will spend
the coming year in Europe.
Mr. J. M. Thompson, '97, is the
publisher of the New Orleans Item
and Mr. Marshall Ballard is the editor. Mr. Thompson has recently
gotten out a very attractive little
booklet, descriptive of his paper,
and the advances it has made in the
last four years. It also tells of the
advantages of New Orleans. In
fact, he was in town a couple
months ago when the delegation
from New Orleans was in Washington advancing the cause of'New
Orleans in the Panama Canal Exposition debate.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 29, 1911.
Editor for this issue, DONALD K. BELT.

We regret to announce that, owing to his graduation, Mr. Taylor
Starck is compelled to resign as editor-in-chief. It seems to us that
no one, except a member of the
Board, can realize how ably Mr.
Starck has filled this office. In
fact, since taking office in February, he has worked untiringly for
the best interests of the paper, sacrificing unlimited amounts 'of time
and energy. He worked unselfishly
for both parts of the paper, realizing that it was quite as necessary
to build up the circulation as the
news service.
We cannot close the year without
expressing our heartiest thanks to
Mr. Ball, the registrar. Throughout the year he has assisted us at
every turn. He has always been
on hand with news, suggestions for
raising money and helpful advice,
and has always been willing.to go
to any amount of trouble to help
us secure information. And we feel
that to him, as much as any one
else, a great part of our success this
year has been due.
We take pleasure in announcing
that Mr. Herbert E. Catlin and Mr.
George Y. Rusk were elected to the
Board at• the last meeting. Mr.
Lindsay Rogers was elected editorin-chief for next year.
Again we wish to remind our
subscribers that we have not received as many renewals as we
would like to have. No doubt you
have simply overlooked it. We
therefore ask that you take the renewal blank out of this—the last
number of THE NEWS-LETTER for
the current year—and mail it to us
without fail this week.

THE NEWS-LETTER: ITS PAST AND
ITS FUTURE.

Standing at the ciose of another
year, it might perhaps nbt be out of
place to sum up what THE NEWS-,
LETTER has done and outline the
plans for its future development.
Two years ago the Board then
publishing THE NEws-LETTER came
to the conclusion that a bi-weekly
publication such as it then was
could be but little more than a failure under existing conditions. At
that time the paper had deteriorated
sadly from its former vigor during
the earlier years of the decade. The
subscription list, in fact, totaled only
sixty-five, of which three were
alumni. According to Dr. Slosson,
indeed, the paper was of "uncertain
character and time of appearance."
The present form was then adopted.
The question was, Could a weekly
newspaper be more successful in
uniting the undergraduates, graduates, meds and alumni?
We believe that our past year's
experience would fully justify an
affirmative conclusion. For since
.then our circulation has increased
700 per cent., of which more
than half are alumni. The total
amount of advertising has quadrupled, and we feel sure that everybody who has subscribed to THE
NEWS-LETTER this year feels that
he has been well repaid. At this
point we might quote one, of the
dozens of letters that we have received recently, from an alumnus
both of the undergraduate department and the Medical School, who
was renewing his subscription:
"THE NEws-LETTER has greatly
improved and is still growing.. It
has put me in touch with J. H. U.
affairs as I haven't been in ten
years. I wouldn't discontinue it at
any cost."
Another proof is that we are now
on the rather restricted exchange
list of the larger college dailies.
And next year the paper will continue in the same way. With good
printing, good paper, and prompt
and correct mailing to the alumni.
It is true that with few exceptions it is impossible to get absolutely fresh material for a paper
which appears but once.a week.
But to disseminate news is not
the sole function of a college paper.
More important than any other reasons for its existence, perhaps, is
the bond of common interest which
it supplies. It surely helps to a
great extent to knit the student
body more firmly together and furnishes another outlet for the superfluous energy directed into so many
side channels. But we also wish
that in the future the undergraduates should feel that the paper belongs to the student body and is not
a close corporation. They should
not feel that the paper is published
entirely apart from the student body
and that a subscription to it is a
business matter pure and simple;
they should consider the Board of
Editors as trustees, who conduct the
paper for the students. Having this
object in view, the Board, at the

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1911
ON RIVER AND SEA
Collecting Trip of the Jamaican Expedition Permanent Laboratory
May Be Established.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

North of the laboratory, but not
quite as far away as Umbrella
Point, there is a large cavern in
the coral cliff that forms a plateau
some distance inland. This cavern
is composed of a number of chambers, all communicating, and these
rooms are the abode of thousands
of bats. So thick are they that one
has no difficulty at all in catching
them. There is a deposit of their
excrement many feet thick on the'
floors of the rooms occupied by the
bats, and we were told that the sugar planters use it as a fertilizer for
their cane fields.
Dr. McCatty, the gentleman from
whom the University rented the
building we used as a laboratory,
owns a large dairy farm near the
station called Catadupa, a short distance from Montego Bay, on the
railroad toward Kingston. At Dr.
McCatty's invitation we had a
very pleasant trip to this farm,
where we were entertained at lunch
by the Doctor and his wife. Catadupa is in the mountains, and the
view from the home was very fine
indeed. European or American cattle cannot live in Jamaica unless
kept in a stable all the time, because
the ticks prove fatal to them, but
the Jamaicans have apparently
,.solved this problem by a process
of interbreeding between these
breeds and the long-horned East
Indian cattle, which are immune to
the ticks.
Like many another neighborhood,
Montego Bay has its "haunted"
house. This is Rose Hall and was
the home of Rose Palmer, who is
reported to have rid herself of two
husbands by the use of poison and
was herself killed by her negro
slaves on a plantation to which her
third husband had banished her.
Rose Hall is quite a large sugar
estate on the north coast of Jamaica, some miles east of Montego
Bay, and Professor Andrews took
us to visit the place. The house has
fallen into great disrepair, but some
old family portraits are still hanging on the walls of the great reception hall, the dining-room and the
library, which form the first story
of the building. The floor of this
story is said to be of solid mahogany. The old negress who is care-,,
taker for the place points out to
one what she says are bloodstains
on the floor of one of the secondstory rooms. In the parish church
at Montego Bay, beside the altar, is
an imposing marble memorial to a
certain Rose Palmer, which consists
of a female figure drooping against
a tall vase.
To the laboratory the natives
were continually bringing all sorts
of animal life—toads, scorpions,
forty-legs, termites, soldier crabs,
the Mongoose, etc. The native fisherman brought us all sorts of queer
fish, from the gorgeous parrot fish
and the yellow and black angel fish

to the swell-toad, with its armor of
J. ALAN FLEDDERMAN
spines, and the horny-skinned trunk
fish. Mention must also be made of

Prof. Henry L. Wilson will
spend the summer in archacological
research in Italy. Sailing soon
after the University closes, Dr. Wilson expects to divide his summer
into three periods. The first of
these will be spent in Pompeii in
studying the latest excavations •
which have been made there. During the second part of the summer
Dr. Wilson expects to make Rome
his headquarters. Here he will
study the latest acquisitions of the
museums and also the new discoveries in the Forum. From Rome,
also, he will take trips to various
parts of Tuscany, where many discoveries have recently been made.
The last part of the summer will be
spent in work upon the excavation.;
carried on in the valley of Aosta.
Dr. Wilson expects to return before the University opens again in
the fall.

Yale-Harvard Baseball.

The Yale and Harvard alumni
have been granted the use of Homewood this Tuesday for a baseball
game. The players will be men
not only from the Hopkins Medical
School and graduate departments,
but from all over Baltimore and vicinity. Although very little is
known of the playing abilities of the
two teams, doubtless the game will
prove both exciting and interesting
for the large attendance expected.

The final meeting of the Arbitration Society for this year took place
in the Donovan room last Wednesday at 5 P. M. An election of officers for the coming year was held,
which brought forth the following
results: President, John S. Dickinson; Vice-President, Taylor Starck ;
Secretary, Hammond; Treasurer, C.
L. Getz; Librarian, Lindsay Rogers. The contest for Treasurer was
particularly close.
It was the feeling of the meeting
that the narrow range of interest to
which the Society has restricted itself in the past would be fatal to
its vitality; and it is therefore likely
that during the coming year the Society will not confine itself to the
study of the peace question, but will
widen its activities to include the
study and discussion of current
events and political history—that it
will, in other words, transform itself, more or less, into a debatihg
society.
A motion was carried to the effect that a sum of money be .yearly
appropriated for the purchase of a
medal, to be offered for the best
essay on a subject connected with
the peace question, that shall be submitted by a member of the freshman class, who is also a member of
the Society.
It is also the aim of the Society
to hold some time (hiring the year
an open, public-speaking contest,
the winner of which will be the
Hopkins representative at the annual Maryland State Intercollegiate
Oratorical Contest.
Hopkins has been for some years
without any attempt toward a debating society; the field seems to be
ripe for one, if only energy enough
can be assembled for its inception.

THE TENNIS TOURNAMENT

SWIMMING POOL AT HOMEWOOD

More Entries Than Last Year—
Consolations and Doubles Are
Unfinished.

Possible Now to Add Two More Sports—
Expected to be Completed
in Six Weeks.

The third annual tennis tournament started on the twenty-second
and has been a great success. There
were thirty-two entries in singles,
six more than last year—a very
creditable showing considering the
small number of students we have.
During the tournament some of the
best tennis which has ever been seen
at Homewood occurred. In the
first round Huck, whom many supposed would • win the tournament,
defeated Clary after the hardest
kind of a three-set match, in which
both men played fine tennis. Afterward Huck defeated Russell and
Dubray and won his way to the
finals, where he was defeated by
Perce in straight sets. In the lower
half Perce had his work cut out for
him from the beginning, afterward
winning from Catlin by default. He
defeated Mullikin in a three-set
match which lasted two days. Then
he defeated Belt by a very narrow
margin in another three-set match.
He also beat Crawford in the semifinals and Huck in the finals.
The consolations and the doubles
have not yet been finished. In the
finals in the consolations "Eddie"
Hulburt and "Jack" Fulton will
play each other. In the doubles Belt
and Dubray will play the winner of
Huck and Perce vs. Post and Clary.
Both teams have won several hard
matches—Belt and Dubray from
Fulton and Gillet, Clary and Post
from Magoffin and Russell, and
Huck and Perce from Corner and
Corner.
Attention, Seniors! It wO'uld be
a good thing if all the present graduating class would sign up for THE
NEWS-LETTER for next year without having to be requested by•mail
in the fall to do so. Just sign the
blank in this copy of the paper and
leave it at THE NEWS-LETTER box.

It was announced this week that
the trustees are now building a
swimming pool at Homewood. The
pool, which will be within sight of
the boulevard, will cover about an
acre of ground. It will be about
seven feet deep. • One end—the
dam—will be of concrete. There
will be a sand bottom. The water
will be supplied from a number of
springs. In addition to being used
as a swimming pool, it will be a
skating pond in the winter. Possibly we may even be able to form
a hockey team. And we ought certainly be able now to have a swimming team. The pool will also be
used in the summer to supply water .to sprinkle the field with when
the cif,r cuts off the supply on, account of drouth.
Let's go overboard!
Dr. Henry G. Barbour (M. D.
'io), fellow in pathology, will spend
the coming year in Europe.
Mr. J. M. Thompson, '97, is the
publisher of the New Orleans Item
and Mr. Marshall Ballard is the editor. Mr. Thompson has recently
gotten out a very attractive little
booklet, descriptive of his paper,
and the advances it has made in the
last four years. It also tells of the
advantages of New Orleans. In
fact, he was in town a couple
months ago when the delegation
from New Orleans was in Washington advancing the cause of'New
Orleans in the Panama Canal Exposition debate.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 29, 1911.
Editor for this issue, DONALD K. BELT.

We regret to announce that, owing to his graduation, Mr. Taylor
Starck is compelled to resign as editor-in-chief. It seems to us that
no one, except a member of the
Board, can realize how ably Mr.
Starck has filled this office. In
fact, since taking office in February, he has worked untiringly for
the best interests of the paper, sacrificing unlimited amounts 'of time
and energy. He worked unselfishly
for both parts of the paper, realizing that it was quite as necessary
to build up the circulation as the
news service.
We cannot close the year without
expressing our heartiest thanks to
Mr. Ball, the registrar. Throughout the year he has assisted us at
every turn. He has always been
on hand with news, suggestions for
raising money and helpful advice,
and has always been willing.to go
to any amount of trouble to help
us secure information. And we feel
that to him, as much as any one
else, a great part of our success this
year has been due.
We take pleasure in announcing
that Mr. Herbert E. Catlin and Mr.
George Y. Rusk were elected to the
Board at• the last meeting. Mr.
Lindsay Rogers was elected editorin-chief for next year.
Again we wish to remind our
subscribers that we have not received as many renewals as we
would like to have. No doubt you
have simply overlooked it. We
therefore ask that you take the renewal blank out of this—the last
number of THE NEWS-LETTER for
the current year—and mail it to us
without fail this week.

THE NEWS-LETTER: ITS PAST AND
ITS FUTURE.

Standing at the ciose of another
year, it might perhaps nbt be out of
place to sum up what THE NEWS-,
LETTER has done and outline the
plans for its future development.
Two years ago the Board then
publishing THE NEws-LETTER came
to the conclusion that a bi-weekly
publication such as it then was
could be but little more than a failure under existing conditions. At
that time the paper had deteriorated
sadly from its former vigor during
the earlier years of the decade. The
subscription list, in fact, totaled only
sixty-five, of which three were
alumni. According to Dr. Slosson,
indeed, the paper was of "uncertain
character and time of appearance."
The present form was then adopted.
The question was, Could a weekly
newspaper be more successful in
uniting the undergraduates, graduates, meds and alumni?
We believe that our past year's
experience would fully justify an
affirmative conclusion. For since
.then our circulation has increased
700 per cent., of which more
than half are alumni. The total
amount of advertising has quadrupled, and we feel sure that everybody who has subscribed to THE
NEWS-LETTER this year feels that
he has been well repaid. At this
point we might quote one, of the
dozens of letters that we have received recently, from an alumnus
both of the undergraduate department and the Medical School, who
was renewing his subscription:
"THE NEws-LETTER has greatly
improved and is still growing.. It
has put me in touch with J. H. U.
affairs as I haven't been in ten
years. I wouldn't discontinue it at
any cost."
Another proof is that we are now
on the rather restricted exchange
list of the larger college dailies.
And next year the paper will continue in the same way. With good
printing, good paper, and prompt
and correct mailing to the alumni.
It is true that with few exceptions it is impossible to get absolutely fresh material for a paper
which appears but once.a week.
But to disseminate news is not
the sole function of a college paper.
More important than any other reasons for its existence, perhaps, is
the bond of common interest which
it supplies. It surely helps to a
great extent to knit the student
body more firmly together and furnishes another outlet for the superfluous energy directed into so many
side channels. But we also wish
that in the future the undergraduates should feel that the paper belongs to the student body and is not
a close corporation. They should
not feel that the paper is published
entirely apart from the student body
and that a subscription to it is a
business matter pure and simple;
they should consider the Board of
Editors as trustees, who conduct the
paper for the students. Having this
object in view, the Board, at the

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1911
ON RIVER AND SEA
Collecting Trip of the Jamaican Expedition Permanent Laboratory
May Be Established.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

North of the laboratory, but not
quite as far away as Umbrella
Point, there is a large cavern in
the coral cliff that forms a plateau
some distance inland. This cavern
is composed of a number of chambers, all communicating, and these
rooms are the abode of thousands
of bats. So thick are they that one
has no difficulty at all in catching
them. There is a deposit of their
excrement many feet thick on the'
floors of the rooms occupied by the
bats, and we were told that the sugar planters use it as a fertilizer for
their cane fields.
Dr. McCatty, the gentleman from
whom the University rented the
building we used as a laboratory,
owns a large dairy farm near the
station called Catadupa, a short distance from Montego Bay, on the
railroad toward Kingston. At Dr.
McCatty's invitation we had a
very pleasant trip to this farm,
where we were entertained at lunch
by the Doctor and his wife. Catadupa is in the mountains, and the
view from the home was very fine
indeed. European or American cattle cannot live in Jamaica unless
kept in a stable all the time, because
the ticks prove fatal to them, but
the Jamaicans have apparently
,.solved this problem by a process
of interbreeding between these
breeds and the long-horned East
Indian cattle, which are immune to
the ticks.
Like many another neighborhood,
Montego Bay has its "haunted"
house. This is Rose Hall and was
the home of Rose Palmer, who is
reported to have rid herself of two
husbands by the use of poison and
was herself killed by her negro
slaves on a plantation to which her
third husband had banished her.
Rose Hall is quite a large sugar
estate on the north coast of Jamaica, some miles east of Montego
Bay, and Professor Andrews took
us to visit the place. The house has
fallen into great disrepair, but some
old family portraits are still hanging on the walls of the great reception hall, the dining-room and the
library, which form the first story
of the building. The floor of this
story is said to be of solid mahogany. The old negress who is care-,,
taker for the place points out to
one what she says are bloodstains
on the floor of one of the secondstory rooms. In the parish church
at Montego Bay, beside the altar, is
an imposing marble memorial to a
certain Rose Palmer, which consists
of a female figure drooping against
a tall vase.
To the laboratory the natives
were continually bringing all sorts
of animal life—toads, scorpions,
forty-legs, termites, soldier crabs,
the Mongoose, etc. The native fisherman brought us all sorts of queer
fish, from the gorgeous parrot fish
and the yellow and black angel fish

5

to the swell-toad, with its armor of
J. ALAN FLEDDERMAN
spines, and the horny-skinned trunk
fish. Mention must also be made of

Prof. Henry L. Wilson will
spend the summer in archacological
research in Italy. Sailing soon
after the University closes, Dr. Wilson expects to divide his summer
into three periods. The first of
these will be spent in Pompeii in
studying the latest excavations •
which have been made there. During the second part of the summer
Dr. Wilson expects to make Rome
his headquarters. Here he will
study the latest acquisitions of the
museums and also the new discoveries in the Forum. From Rome,
also, he will take trips to various
parts of Tuscany, where many discoveries have recently been made.
The last part of the summer will be
spent in work upon the excavation.;
carried on in the valley of Aosta.
Dr. Wilson expects to return before the University opens again in
the fall.

Yale-Harvard Baseball.

The Yale and Harvard alumni
have been granted the use of Homewood this Tuesday for a baseball
game. The players will be men
not only from the Hopkins Medical
School and graduate departments,
but from all over Baltimore and vicinity. Although very little is
known of the playing abilities of the
two teams, doubtless the game will
prove both exciting and interesting
for the large attendance expected.

What the"Med*" Will Do This Summer.

A large number of the secondyear class of the Medical School
will work during the summer
months in the Hopkins Surgical
Dispensary.
E. W. Bridgeman, D. C. Street,
and H. H. Loos (A. B. '08) have
sailed for the Canal Zone, Panama,
to work in the government hospitals
for several months.
Miss E. M. Rockwood, of the
second year of the Medical School,
is rapidly recovering from a recent
illness.
During July and August Mr.
John K. Ormond, of the Medical
School, will be in charge of "Camp
Pok-o-Moonshine," Willsboro, New
York.
Mr. John J. Morton, of the second year of the Medical School,
will be expert collector at the Marine Biological Laboratory, Woods
Hole, Mass.., during this summer.

The final meeting of the Arbitration Society for this year took place
in the Donovan room last Wednesday at 5 P. M. An election of officers for the coming year was held,
which brought forth the following
results: President, John S. Dickinson; Vice-President, Taylor Starck ;
Secretary, Hammond; Treasurer, C.
L. Getz; Librarian, Lindsay Rogers. The contest for Treasurer was
particularly close.
It was the feeling of the meeting
that the narrow range of interest to
which the Society has restricted itself in the past would be fatal to
its vitality; and it is therefore likely
that during the coming year the Society will not confine itself to the
study of the peace question, but will
widen its activities to include the
study and discussion of current
events and political history—that it
will, in other words, transform itself, more or less, into a debatihg
society.
A motion was carried to the effect that a sum of money be .yearly
appropriated for the purchase of a
medal, to be offered for the best
essay on a subject connected with
the peace question, that shall be submitted by a member of the freshman class, who is also a member of
the Society.
It is also the aim of the Society
to hold some time (hiring the year
an open, public-speaking contest,
the winner of which will be the
Hopkins representative at the annual Maryland State Intercollegiate
Oratorical Contest.
Hopkins has been for some years
without any attempt toward a debating society; the field seems to be
ripe for one, if only energy enough
can be assembled for its inception.
